column2: Event
Earliest reports of unknown dairy cattle disease in Texas
USDA declares ongoing outbreak of HPAI in commercial poultry farms
Unknown dairy cattle illness first reported publicly by the Texas Animal Health Commission
Commercial poultry farm positive for HPAI in Essex County, MA, USA
Cattle transferred from a dairy farm in Texas (that later tested positive) to a farm in Ohio that tested positive on April 2
Samples collected from goats in Minnesota (n=3) that were positive for H5N1 & sequenced (posted March 27th)
Wastewater collected in North Texas tests positive for H5. These data weren't made public until Apr 29th
Commercial turkey farm positive for HAPI in Hutchinson County, SD, USA
HPAI detected in wild birds in Texas
Concerns voiced about unknown illness in dairy cattle in Texas
Samples collected from dairy cattle in Texas (n=6) that were positive for H5N1 & Sequenced (posted Mar 27th n = 5 and Apr 5th n = 1)
Minnesota Board of Animal Health announces H5N1 in goats
Additional testing was initiated due to concerns about an unknown infection in dairy cattle
Mystery illness reported in dairy cattle in Texas and New Mexico
PAHO warns of increased HPAI in mammals in the Americas
Texas confirms H5N1 in dairy cattle
Five viral genomes from dairy cattle posted publicly (collected in TX on Mar 20th)
Three viral genomes from goats posted publicly (collected in MN on Mar 8th)
A viral sample was collected from a human in Texas that was positive for H5N1 & sequenced (posted Apr 2)
USDA confirms 10 positive dairy farms in three states (Texas (7), Kansas (2), and Michigan (1))
First human infection reported in Texas
USDA confirms H5N1 in dairy cattle in New Mexico
USDA confirms 15 positive dairy farms in five states (Texas (7), Kansas (3), New Mexico (3), Idaho (1), and Michigan (1))
First genome collected from a human posted online (collected in TX on Mar 28th)
Dairy farm in Idaho confirmed positive for H5N1
Poultry farm in Parmer County, Texas confirmed positive for H5N1
USDA confirms 16 positive dairy farms in six states (Texas (7), Kansas (3), New Mexico (3), Idaho (1), Michigan (1), and Ohio (1))
Ohio Department of Agriculture announces positive H5N1 cases in a dairy farm in Wood County
commercial poultry farm in Ionia, MI tests positive for HPAI
USDA confirms 18 positive dairy farms in six states (Texas (9), Kansas (3), New Mexico (3), Idaho (1), Michigan (1), and Ohio (1))
USDA confirms 19 positive dairy farms in six states (Texas (9), Kansas (3), New Mexico (3), Idaho (1), Michigan (2), and Ohio (1))
One viral genome from dairy cattle posted publicly (collected in TX on Mar 20th)
USDA confirms 21 positive dairy farms in six states (Texas (9), Kansas (3), New Mexico (5), Idaho (1), Michigan (2), and Ohio (1))
USDA confirms 25 positive dairy farms in eight states (Texas (10), Kansas (3), New Mexico (6), Idaho (1), Michigan (2), South Dakota (1), North Carolina (1), and Ohio (1))
USDA confirms 5 positive commercial poultry farms positive for HPAI in four states since Mar 2024 (Michigan (2), Texas (1), South Dakota (1), and Massachusetts (1))
USDA confirms 27 positive dairy farms in eight states (Texas (11), Kansas (3), New Mexico (7), Idaho (1), Michigan (2), South Dakota (1), North Carolina (1), and Ohio (1))
USDA confirms 6 positive commercial poultry farms positive for HPAI in five states since Mar 2024 (Michigan (2), Texas (1), South Dakota (1), Massachusetts (1), and Kansas (1))
USDA confirms 7 positive commercial poultry farms positive for HPAI in six states since Mar 2024 (Michigan (2), Texas (1), South Dakota (1), Massachusetts (1), Minnesota (1), and Kansas (1))

USDA confirms 8 positive commercial poultry farms positive for HPAI in seven states since Mar 2024 (Michigan (2), Texas (1), South Dakota (1), Massachusetts (1), Minnesota (1), New Mexico (1), and Kansas (1))
USDA confirms 29 positive dairy farms in eight states (Texas (11), Kansas (3), New Mexico (7), Idaho (1), Michigan (4), South Dakota (1), North Carolina (1), and Ohio (1))
USDA confirms 30 positive dairy farms in eight states (Texas (11), Kansas (3), New Mexico (7), Idaho (1), Michigan (5), South Dakota (1), North Carolina (1), and Ohio (1))

USDA confirms 9 positive commercial poultry farms positive for HPAI in seven states since Mar 2024 (Michigan (2), Texas (1), South Dakota (1), Massachusetts (1), Minnesota (1), New Mexico (2), and Kansas (1))
10 viral genomes from felines posted publicly (collection date and location not provided)

USDA confirms 10 positive commercial poultry farms positive for HPAI in seven states since Mar 2024 (Michigan (3), Texas (1), South Dakota (1), Massachusetts (1), Minnesota (1), New Mexico (2), and Kansas (1))
USDA confirms 34 positive dairy farms in eight states (Texas (12), Kansas (4), New Mexico (8), Idaho (1), Michigan (6), South Dakota (1), North Carolina (1), and Ohio (1))

USDA confirms 12 positive commercial poultry farms positive for HPAI in seven states since Mar 2024 (Michigan (4), Texas (1), South Dakota (1), Massachusetts (1), Minnesota (1), New Mexico (3), and Kansas (1))
USDA confirms 35 positive dairy farms in eight states (Texas (12), Kansas (4), New Mexico (8), Idaho (2), Michigan (6), South Dakota (1), North Carolina (1), and Ohio (1))
USDA posts 239 additional H5N1 genomes from birds and dairy cattle
Analysis of 239 additional genomes suggests cow-to-cow transmission
Analysis of 239 additional genomes suggests a single origin for the ongoing dairy cattle outbreak

USDA confirms 13 positive commercial poultry farms positive for HPAI in seven states since Mar 2024 (Michigan (5), Texas (1), South Dakota (1), Massachusetts (1), Minnesota (1), New Mexico (3), and Kansas (1))
USDA announces mandatory testing for movement of dairy cattle across state borders
NIH NIAID researchers fail to find live virus in pasturized milk that was PCR positive for H5N1
Evidence that 30 - 40% of commercial milk samples were PCR positive for H5N1
USDA confirms 36 positive dairy farms in nine states (Texas (12), Kansas (4), New Mexico (8), Idaho (2), Michigan (6), South Dakota (1), North Carolina (1), Ohio (1), and Colorado (1))

USDA confirms 14 positive commercial poultry farms positive for HPAI in seven states since Mar 2024 (Michigan (6), Texas (1), South Dakota (1), Massachusetts (1), Minnesota (1), New Mexico (3), and Kansas (1))
CDC expands reccomendations to protect farm workers
Metadata was extracted and populated for the dairy cattle genomes posted by the USDA on Apr 21st
CDC publishes a paper on the outbreak of H5N1 in cats and dairy cows
A pre-print shows that H5 is present in US wastewater. They discuss how milk products being dumped into wastewater may explain this pattern.
The USDA posted a preprint on cattle movement, genomic surveillance, and epidemiology related to H5N1
USDA announces find no evidence of H5N1 in beef cattle nor derived beef produtcs
More extensive testing by the FDA concludes that pasteurization inactivates H5N1 in dairy products

USDA confirms 16 positive commercial poultry farms positive for HPAI in seven states since Mar 2024 (Michigan (7), Texas (1), South Dakota (1), Massachusetts (1), Minnesota (2), New Mexico (3), and Kansas (1))
New pre-print shows that avian- and human-influenza A sialic acid receptor types are present in the mammary glands of dairy cattle

CDC wastewater data showed above average influenza A activity in 9 sites in six states (California (3), Illinoise (2), Texas (2), Alaska, Florida, Kansas). These analyses cannot distinguish seasonal influenza A from H5N1
USDA informs WOAH that infected dairy cattle with H5N1 can experience diarrhea as a symptom
USDA confirms 37 positive dairy farms in nine states (Texas (12), Kansas (4), New Mexico (8), Idaho (3), Michigan (6), South Dakota (1), North Carolina (1), Ohio (1), and Colorado (1))
USDA confirms 42 positive dairy farms in nine states (Texas (12), Kansas (4), New Mexico (8), Idaho (3), Michigan (10), South Dakota (1), North Carolina (1), Ohio (1), and Colorado (2))
USDA confirms 43 positive dairy farms in nine states (Texas (13), Kansas (4), New Mexico (8), Idaho (3), Michigan (10), South Dakota (1), North Carolina (1), Ohio (1), and Colorado (2))
USDA confirms an H5N1 infected bird at a wild bird market in California.
New pre-print shows that 9 wastewater testing sites in Texas containg H5N1 during the study period of March 4th 2024 - April 25th 2024
USDA confirms 44 positive dairy farms in nine states (Texas (13), Kansas (4), New Mexico (8), Idaho (3), Michigan (11), South Dakota (1), North Carolina (1), Ohio (1), and Colorado (2))

USDA confirms 17 positive commercial poultry farms positive for HPAI in eight states since Mar 2024 (Michigan (7), Texas (1), South Dakota (1), Massachusetts (1), Minnesota (2), New Mexico (3), Kansas (1), and Idaho (1))
The USDA announced a new Federal Order to support expanded testing and mitigation measures for H5N1 impacted dairy farms
USDA confirms 46 positive dairy farms in nine states (Texas (13), Kansas (4), New Mexico (8), Idaho (4), Michigan (12), South Dakota (1), North Carolina (1), Ohio (1), and Colorado (2))

CDC wastewater data showed above average influenza A activity in 11 sites in five states (California (5), Texas (3), New York, Florida, Kansas). These analyses cannot distinguish seasonal influenza A from H5N1

The LA Times reported that 59 of 190 WasterSCAN surveillance sites in the US showed elevated, out-of-season influenza A spikes. These data do not separate H5N1 from seasonal influenza nor the source of the influenza found in the wastewater
The Canadian Food Inspection Agency announced that 142 milk samples in Canada were negative for H5N1 fragments

The US CDC posted a public dashboard show influenza A levels in NWSS sites across the US. This dashboard does not distinguish between influenza A subtypes, i.e., seasonal flu and H5N1 are grouped together
USDA confirms 49 positive dairy farms in nine states (Texas (13), Kansas (4), New Mexico (8), Idaho (5), Michigan (14), South Dakota (1), North Carolina (1), Ohio (1), and Colorado (2))
USDA announces that ground beef innoculated with H5N1 is safe to eat if heated above 145F (63C). The USDA noted that testing has not identified any H5N1 infected beef cattle nor beef products
The CDC announced that wastewater surveillance site in Florida and Illinois show high levels of Influenza A that may indicated undected H5N1 infected dairy herds
The CDC announced that no elevated levels of emergency room visits for respiratory illness have been indentified in areas near H5N1 infected dairy farms
The CDC announced that none of the 49 dairy farms known to have had H5N1 infected cows sold raw milk for human consumption
The USDA announced 22M in new funding for disease surveillance/prevention. Some of these funds will go towards H5N1 and HPAI.
USDA confirms 51 positive dairy farms in nine states (Texas (13), Kansas (4), New Mexico (8), Idaho (5), Michigan (15), South Dakota (12, North Carolina (1), Ohio (1), and Colorado (2))
USDA confirms 55 positive dairy farms in nine states (Texas (14), Kansas (4), New Mexico (8), Idaho (7), Michigan (15), South Dakota (2), North Carolina (1), Ohio (1), and Colorado (3))
USDA confirms 57 positive dairy farms in nine states (Texas (14), Kansas (4), New Mexico (8), Idaho (9), Michigan (15), South Dakota (2), North Carolina (1), Ohio (1), and Colorado (3))
USDA confirms 63 positive dairy farms in nine states (Colorado (4), Idaho (9), Kansas (4), Michigan (19), New Mexico (8), North Carolina (1), Ohio (1), South Dakota (3), Texas (14))
USDA confirms 66 positive dairy farms in nine states (Colorado (4), Idaho (9), Kansas (4), Michigan (20), New Mexico (8), North Carolina (1), Ohio (1), South Dakota (4), Texas (15))
USDA confirms 67 positive dairy farms in nine states (Colorado (4), Idaho (10), Kansas (4), Michigan (20), New Mexico (8), North Carolina (1), Ohio (1), South Dakota (4), Texas (15))
USDA confirms 69 positive dairy farms in nine states (Colorado (4), Idaho (10), Kansas (4), Michigan (22), New Mexico (8), North Carolina (1), Ohio (1), South Dakota (4), Texas (15))
USDA confirms 70 positive dairy farms in nine states (Colorado (4), Idaho (10), Kansas (4), Michigan (23), New Mexico (8), North Carolina (1), Ohio (1), South Dakota (4), Texas (15))
USDA confirms 78 positive dairy farms in nine states (Colorado (4), Idaho (18), Kansas (4), Michigan (23), New Mexico (8), North Carolina (1), Ohio (1), South Dakota (4), Texas (15))
